children.name: --TRT
children.-DESCRIPTION: The topic for the intervention observation, usually the verbatim name of the treatment, drug, medicine, or therapy given during the dosing interval for the observation.

children.name: --MODIFY
children.-DESCRIPTION: If the value for --TRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

children.name: --DECOD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Standardized or dictionary-Derived name of the topic variable, --TRT, or the modified topic variable (--MODIFY), if applicable. Equivalent to the generic drug name in WHO Drug, or a term in SNOMED, ICD9, or other published or sponsor-defined dictionaries.

children.name: --CAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a category of topic-variable values.

children.name: --SCAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a further categorization of --CAT values.

children.name: --PRESP
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used when a specific intervention is pre-specified on a CRF. Values should be "Y" or null.

children.name: --OCCUR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to record whether a pre-specified intervention occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific intervention is solicited.

children.name: --STAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate when a question about the occurrence of a pre-specified intervention was not answered. Should be null or have a value of NOT DONE.

children.name: --REASND
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reason not done. Used in conjunction with --STAT when value is NOT DONE.

children.name: --INDC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Denotes the indication for the intervention (e.g., why the therapy was taken or administered).

children.name: --CLAS
children.-DESCRIPTION: Class for a medication or treatment, often obtained from a coding dictionary.

children.name: --CLASCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to represent code for --CLAS.

children.name: --DOSE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Amount of --TRT given. Not populated when --DOSTXT is populated.

children.name: --DOSTXT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Dosing information collected in text form. Examples: <1 per day, 200-400. Not populated when --DOSE is populated.

children.name: --DOSU
children.-DESCRIPTION: Units for --DOSE, --DOSTOT, or --DOSTXT (Examples: ng, mg, mg/kg).

children.name: --DOSFRM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Dose form for the treatment. Examples: TABLET, CAPSULE.

children.name: --DOSFRQ
children.-DESCRIPTION: Usually expressed as the number of doses given per a specific interval. Examples: QD, BID, TID, QID.

children.name: --DOSTOT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Total daily dose of --TRT using the units in --DOSU. Used when dosing is collected as Total Daily Dose.
children.-Comments: Derived based on --DOSE and --DOSFRQ

children.name: --DOSRGM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Text description of the (intended) schedule or regimen for the Intervention. Examples: TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF.

children.name: --ROUTE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Route of administration for the intervention. Examples: ORAL, INTRAVENOUS.

children.name: --LOT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Lot number for the intervention described in --TRT.

children.name: --LOC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Anatomical location of an intervention, such as an injection site. Example: RIGHT ARM for an injection.

children.name: --TRTV
children.-DESCRIPTION: Vehicle for administration of treatment, such as a liquid in which the treatment drug is dissolved. Example: SALINE.

children.name: --VAMT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Amount of the treatment vehicle administered or given.

children.name: --VAMTU
children.-DESCRIPTION: Units for the treatment vehicle. Examples: mL, mg.

children.name: --ADJ
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted. Examples ADVERSE EVENT, INSUFFICIENT RESPONSE, NON-MEDICAL REASON.

children.name: --TERM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Topic variable for an event observation, which is the verbatim or pre-specified name of the event.

children.name: --MODIFY
children.-DESCRIPTION: If the value for --TERM is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

children.name: --LLT
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA Lowest Level Term.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --LLTCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA Lowest Level Term code.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --DECOD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Dictionary or sponsor-defined Derived text description of the topic variable, --TERM, or the modified topic variable (--MODIFY), if applicable. Equivalent to the Preferred Term (PT in MedDRA).
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --PTCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA Preferred Term code.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --HLT
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA High Level Term from the primary path.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --HLTCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA High Level Term code from the primary path.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --HLGT
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA High Level Group Term from the primary path.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --HLGTCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA High Level Group Term code from the primary path.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --CAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a category of topic-variable values.

children.name: --SCAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a further categorization of --CAT values.

children.name: --PRESP
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate whether the event described by --TERM was pre-specified on a CRF. Value is Y for pre-specified events, null for spontaneously reported events.

children.name: --OCCUR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to record whether a pre-specified event occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific event is solicited.

children.name: --STAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate when a question about the occurrence of a pre-specified event was not answered. Should be null or have a value of NOT DONE.

children.name: --REASND
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reason not done. Used in conjunction with --STAT when its value is NOT DONE.

children.name: --BODSYS
children.-DESCRIPTION: Body system or system organ class from a standard hierarchy (e.g. MedDRA) associated with an event. Example: GASTROINTESTINAL DISORDERS.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --BDSYCD
children.text: Body System or Organ Class Code
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA System Organ Class code used for analysis.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --SOC
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA primary System Organ Class.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --SOCCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: MedDRA primary System Organ Class code.
children.-Comments: MedDRA version 13.1

children.name: --LOC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes anatomical location relevant for the event. Example: LEFT ARM for skin rash.

children.name: --SEV
children.-DESCRIPTION: The severity or intensity of the event. Examples: MILD, MODERATE, SEVERE.

children.name: --SER
children.-DESCRIPTION: Is this is a serious event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --ACN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes changes made to the study treatment as a result of the event. Examples: DOSE INCREASED, DOSE NOT CHANGED.

children.name: --ACNOTH
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes other actions taken as a result of the event that are unrelated to dose adjustments of study treatment.

children.name: --REL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Records the investigator's opinion as to the causality of the event to the treatment. ICH E2A and E2B examples include NOT RELATED, UNLIKELY RELATED, POSSIBLY RELATED, RELATED.

children.name: --RELNST
children.-DESCRIPTION: An opinion as to whether the event may have been due to a treatment other than study drug. Example: "MORE LIKELY RELATED TO ASPIRIN USE."

children.name: --PATT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate the pattern of the event over time. Examples: INTERMITTENT, CONTINUOUS, SINGLE EVENT.

children.name: --OUT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of the outcome of an event. Examples: RECOVERED/RESOLVED, FATAL.

children.name: --SCAN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Was the event associated with the development of cancer? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SCONG
children.-DESCRIPTION: Was the event associated with congenital anomaly or birth defect? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SDISAB
children.-DESCRIPTION: Did the event result in persistent or significant disability/incapacity? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SDTH
children.-DESCRIPTION: Did the event result in death? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SHOSP
children.-DESCRIPTION: Did the event require or prolong hospitalization? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SLIFE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Was the event life threatening? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SOD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Did the event occur with an overdose? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --SMIE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Do additional categories for seriousness apply? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --CONTRT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Was another treatment given because of the occurrence of the event? Valid values are "Y" and "N".

children.name: --TOX
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of toxicity quantified by --TOXGR such as NCI CTCAE Short Name. Examples: HYPERCALCEMIA, HYPOCALCEMIA. Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define.xml document.
children.-Comments: Derived based on AECTC V4.0

children.name: --TOXGR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Records toxicity grade using a standard toxicity scale (such as the NCI CTCAE). Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define.xml document.
children.-Comments: Derived based on AECTC V4.0

children.name: --TESTCD
children.text: Short Name of Measurement, Test or Exam
children.-DESCRIPTION: Short character value for --TEST used as a column name when converting a dataset from a vertical format to a horizontal format. The short value can be up to 8 characters. Examples: PLAT, SYSBP, RRMIN, EYEEXAM.

children.name: --TEST
children.text: Name of Measurement, Test or Exam
children.-DESCRIPTION: Long name For --TESTCD. Examples: Platelet, Systolic Blood Pressure, Summary (Min) RR Duration, Eye Examination.

children.name: --MODIFY
children.-DESCRIPTION: If the value of --ORRES is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.

children.name: --OBJ
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used in domains modeled as Findings About Events or Findings About Interventions. Describes the event or intervention whose property is being measured in --TESTCD/--TEST. Example: an event of vomiting which has findings, where --OBJ = "VOMIT" and the volume of VOMIT is being measured where --TESTCD = "VOLUME".

children.name: --CAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a category of topic-variable values. Examples: HEMATOLOGY, URINALYSIS, CHEMISTRY, HAMILTON DEPRESSION SCALE, SF36.

children.name: --SCAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to define a further categorization of --CAT values. Example: DIFFERENTIAL.

children.name: --POS
children.-DESCRIPTION: Position of the subject during a measurement or examination. Examples: SUPINE, STANDING, SITTING.

children.name: --BODSYS
children.-DESCRIPTION: Body System or Organ Class that is involved for a finding from the standard hierarchy for dictionary-coded results. Example: MedDRA SOC.

children.name: --ORRES
children.text: Result or Finding in Original Units
children.-DESCRIPTION: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected. Examples: 120, <1, POS.

children.name: --ORRESU
children.-DESCRIPTION: Unit for --ORRES. Examples: IN, LB, kg/L.

children.name: --ORNRLO
children.-DESCRIPTION: Lower end of normal range or reference range for results stored in --ORRES.

children.name: --ORNRHI
children.-DESCRIPTION: Upper end of normal range or reference range for results stored in --ORRES.

children.name: --STRESC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Contains the result value for all findings, copied or Derived from --ORRES in a standard format or in standard units. --STRESC should store all results or findings in character format; if results are numeric, they should also be stored in numeric format in --STRESN. For example, if various tests have results "NONE", "NEG", and "NEGATIVE" in --ORRES and these results effectively have the same meaning, they could be represented in standard format in --STRESC as "NEGATIVE".
children.-Comments: If data collected in non-standard units, then data is converted using standard conversion factors to standard units; else equal to --ORRES.

children.name: --STRESN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used for continuous or numeric results or findings in standard format; copied in numeric format from --STRESC. --STRESN should store all numeric test results or findings.
children.-Comments: Equal to numeric value of --STRESC

children.name: --STRESU
children.-DESCRIPTION: Standardized units used for --STRESC and --STRESN. Example: mol/L.

children.name: --STNRLO
children.-DESCRIPTION: Lower end of normal range or reference range for standardized results (e.g., --STRESC, --STRESN) represented in standardized units (--STRESU).
children.-Comments: If data collected in non-standard units, then --ORNRLO is converted using standard conversion factors to standard units; else equal to numeric value of --ORNRLO.

children.name: --STNRHI
children.-DESCRIPTION: Upper end of normal range or reference range for standardized results (e.g., --STRESC, --STRESN) represented in standardized units (--STRESU).
children.-Comments: If data collected in non-standard units, then --ORNRHI is converted using standard conversion factors to standard units; else equal to numeric value of --ORNRHI.

children.name: --STNRC
children.text: Reference Range for Char Rslt-Std Units
children.-DESCRIPTION: For normal range or reference range values for results stored in --STRESC that are character in ordinal or categorical scale. Example: Negative to Trace.

children.name: --NRIND
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate the value is outside the normal range or reference range. May be defined by --ORNRLO and --ORNRHI or other objective criteria. Examples: Y, N; HIGH, LOW; NORMAL; ABNORMAL.
children.-Comments: Reference Range Indicator based upon standard results and ranges.

children.name: --RESCAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to categorize the result of a finding. Example: MALIGNANT or BENIGN for tumor findings.

children.name: --STAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate that a question was not asked or a test was not done, or a test was attempted but did not generate a result. Should be null or have a value of NOT DONE.

children.name: --REASND
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reason not done. Used in conjunction with --STAT when value is NOT DONE.

children.name: --XFN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Filename for an external file, such as one for an ECG waveform or a medical image.

children.name: --NAM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Name or identifier of the vendor (e.g., laboratory) that provided the test results.

children.name: --LOINC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) code for the topic variable such as a lab test.

children.name: --SPEC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement. Examples: SERUM, PLASMA, URINE.

children.name: --ANTREG
children.-DESCRIPTION: Defines the specific anatomical or biological region of a tissue, organ specimen or the region from which the specimen is obtained, as defined in the Protocol, such as a section or part of what is described in the --SPEC variable. Examples: CORTEX,MEDULLA, MUCOSA

children.name: --SPCCND
children.-DESCRIPTION: Defines the condition of the specimen. Example: CLOUDY.

children.name: --SPCUFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes the usability of the specimen for the test. The value will be N if the specimen is not usable, and null if the specimenis usable.

children.name: --LOC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Location relevant to the collection of the measurement. Example: RECTAL for temperature, LEFT ARM for blood pressure or V1 for an ECG lead.

children.name: --LAT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing laterality

children.name: --DIR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing directionality

children.name: --PORTOT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Qualifier for anatomical location or specimen further detailing the distribution, which means arrangement of, apportioning of.

children.name: --METHOD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Method of the test or examination. Examples: EIA (Enzyme Immunoassay), ELECTROPHORESIS, DIPSTICK.

children.name: --LEAD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Lead or leads identified to capture the measurement for a testfrom an instrument. Examples: LEAD I, LEAD V2, LEAD CM5.

children.name: --CSTATE
children.-DESCRIPTION: The consciousness state of the subject at the time of measurement. Examples: CONSCIOUS, SEMI-CONSCIOUS,UNCONSCIOUS

children.name: --BLFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Indicator used to identify a baseline value. Should be Y or null.
children.-Comments: Derivation of baseline: Safety subjects only: --BLFL=Y for last non missing record on or before the first dose date (RFSTDTC).

children.name: --FAST
children.-DESCRIPTION: Indicator used to identify fasting status. Valid values include Y, N, U or null if not relevant.

children.name: --DRVFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to indicate a Derived record (e.g., a record that represents the average of other records such as a computed baseline). Should be Y or null.

children.name: --EVAL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Role of the person who provided the evaluation. Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., Assigned by a person or a group). Examples: ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, VENDOR.

children.name: --EVALID
children.-DESCRIPTION: The Evaluator Specified variable is used in conjunction with TUEVAL to provide an additional level of detail.

children.name: --ACPTFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: In cases where more than one independent assessor (e.g. RADIOLOGIST 1 & RADIOLOGIST 2) provide independent assessments at the same time point this flag identifies the record that is considered to be the accepted assessment.

children.name: --TOX
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of toxicity quantified by --TOXGR such as NCI CTCAE Short Name. Examples: HYPERCALCEMIA, HYPOCALCEMIA. Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define.xml document.
children.-Comments: Derived from results and reference range based on AECTC V4.0

children.name: --TOXGR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Records toxicity grade using a standard toxicity scale (such as the NCI CTCAE). Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define data definition document.
children.-Comments: Derived from results and reference range based on AECTC V4.0

children.name: --SEV
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes the severity or intensity of a particular finding. Examples: MILD, MODERATE, SEVERE.

children.name: --DTHREL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Describes the relationship of a particular finding to the death of a subject.

children.name: --LLOQ
children.-DESCRIPTION: Indicates the lower limit of quantitation for an assay. Units will be those used for --STRESU.

children.name: --EXCLFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Indicates whether the values in the result variables for this record should be excluded from summary statistical calculations such as Mean, Standard Deviation, and Count (and others). Expected to be Y or null. --EXCLFL should not be used when --STAT is NOT DONE. Not to be used with human clinical trials.

children.name: --REASEX
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reason excluded from statistics. Used in conjunction with --EXCLFL when its value is Y. Not to be used with human clinical trials

children.name: SUBJID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Subject identifier, which must be unique within the study. Often the ID of the subject as recorded on a CRF.

children.name: RFSTDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reference Start Date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to date/time when subject was first exposed to study treatment. Required for all randomized subjects; will be null for all subjects who did not meet the milestone the date requires, such as screen failures or unAssigned subjects.
children.-Comments: For safety subjects equal to first date/time of study drug. Null for subjects who did not take study drug.

children.name: RFENDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Reference End Date/time for the subject in ISO 8601 character format. Usually equivalent to the date/time when subject was determined to have ended the trial, and often equivalent to date/time of last exposure to study treatment. Required for all randomized subjects; null for screen failures or unAssigned subjects.
children.-Comments: For safety subjects equal to last date/time of study drug. Null for subjects who did not take study drug.

children.name: RFXSTDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: First date of exposure to any Protocol-specified treatment or therapy for the subject in ISO 8601 character format.
children.-Comments: Equal to first date/time of study drug. Null for subjects who did not take study drug.

children.name: RFXENDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Last date of exposure to any Protocol-specified treatment or therapy for the subject in ISO 8601 character format.
children.-Comments: Equal to last date/time of study drug. Null for subjects who did not take study drug.

children.name: RFICDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Date/time of informed consent in ISO 8601 character format.

children.name: RFPENDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Date/time when subject ended participation or follow-up in a trial, in ISO 8601 character format. Should correspond to the last known date of contact.
children.-Comments: Last known date of contact

children.name: DTHDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Date/time of death for any subject who died, in ISO 8601 format. Should represent the date/time that is captured in the clinical-trial database.

children.name: DTHFL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Indicates the subject died. Should be Y or null. Should be populated even when the death date is unknown.

children.name: SITEID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Unique identifier for a site within a study.

children.name: INVID
children.-DESCRIPTION: An identifier to describe the Investigator for the study. May be used in addition to the SITEID. Not needed if SITEID is equivalent to INVID.

children.name: INVNAM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Name of the investigator for a site.

children.name: BRTHDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Date/time of birth of the subject in ISO 8601 character format.

children.name: AGE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Age expressed in AGEU. May be Derived as (RFSTDTC-BRTHDTC), but BRTHDTC may not be available in all cases (due to subject privacy concerns).
children.-Comments: Year part of (RFICDTC - BRTHDTC)

children.name: AGEU
children.-DESCRIPTION: Units associated with AGE.

children.name: SEX
children.-DESCRIPTION: Sex of the subject.

children.name: RACE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Race of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, September 2005) for guidance regarding the collection of race .

children.name: ETHNIC
children.-DESCRIPTION: The ethnicity of the subject. Sponsors should refer to "Collection of Race and Ethnicity Data in Clinical Trials" (FDA, September 2005) for guidance regarding the collection of ethnicity.

children.name: ARMCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: ARMCD is limited to 20 characters and does not have special character restrictions.

children.name: ARM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Name of the Arm to which the subject was Assigned.

children.name: ACTARMCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Short name for the actual Arm in which the subject participated during the trial, limited to 20 characters.
children.-Comments: Derived from arm code in Trial Arm (TA) based on Actual Assignment.

children.name: ACTARM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of the actual Arm in which the subject participated during thetrial.
children.-Comments: Derived from description of arm in TRIAL ARM (TA) based on Actual Assignment.

children.name: COUNTRY
children.-DESCRIPTION: Country of the investigational site at which the subject participated in the trial in ISO 3166 three-character format.

children.name: RDOMAIN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Domain Abbreviation of the parent record(s). Null for records collected on general comments or additional information CRF page.

children.name: IDVAR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifying variable in the parent dataset that identifies the record(s) to which the comment applies. Examples AESEQ or CMGRPID. Used only when individual comments are related to domain records. Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.

children.name: IDVARVAL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Value of identifying variable of the parent record(s). Null for comments collected on separate CRFs.

children.name: --UPDES
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned Element. Used only if ETCD has the value of "UNPLAN".

children.name: COREF
children.-DESCRIPTION: Sponsor-defined reference associated with the comment. May be the CRF page number (e.g. 650), or a module name (e.g. DEMOG), or a combination of information that identifies the reference (e.g. 650-VITALS-VISIT 2).

children.name: COVAL
children.-DESCRIPTION: The text of the comment. Text over 200 characters can be added to additional columns COVAL1-COVALn.

children.name: COEVAL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Used to describe the originator of the comment. Example: CENTRAL REVIEWER.

children.name: ETCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: ETCD (the companion to ELEMENT) is limited to 8 characters and does not have special character restrictions. These values should be short for ease of use in programming, but it is not expected that ETCD will need to serve as a variable name.

children.name: ELEMENT
children.-DESCRIPTION: The name of the Element. If ETCD has a value of "UNPLAN" then ELEMENT should be Null.

children.name: SESTDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Start date/time for an Element for each subject, represented in ISO 8601 character format.

children.name: SEENDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: End date/time of an Element for each subject, represented in ISO 8601 character format.

children.name: SEUPDES
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned Element. Used only if ETCD has the value of "UNPLAN".

children.name: IDVAR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifying variable in the dataset that identifies the related record(s). Examples: --SEQ and --GRPID.

children.name: IDVARVAL
children.-DESCRIPTION: Value of identifying variable of the related parent record(s). Used only when individual records are being related.

children.name: RELTYPE
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifying the hierarchical level of the records in the relationship. Values must be either ONE or MANY. Used only when datasets are being related.

children.name: RELID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Unique value within a USUBJID that identifies the relationship. All records for the same USUBJID that have the same RELID are considered related/associated. RELID can be any value the sponsor chooses, and is only meaningful within the RELREC dataset to identify the related/associated Domain records.

children.name: STUDYID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Study Identifier of the domain record(s).

children.name: RDOMAIN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Two-character abbreviation for the domain of the parent record(s).

children.name: USUBJID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product
children.-Comments: Concatenate STUDYID, SITEID and SUBJID, separated by "-".

children.name: --UPDES
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of what happened to the subject during an unplanned visit. Null for Protocol-defined visits.

children.name: ARMCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Short 8-character version of ARM, used for programming.

children.name: ARM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Name given to Arm or treatment group.

children.name: ETCD
children.-DESCRIPTION: Short 8-character name for ELEMENT, used for programming. If an encountered Element differs from the planned ELEMENT to the point that it is considered a new ELEMENT, then use UNPLAN as the value for ETCD to represent this Element.

children.name: ELEMENT
children.-DESCRIPTION: The name of the Element. If an encountered Element differs from the planned ELEMENT to the point that it is considered a new ELEMENT, then ELEMENT should be null.

children.name: STUDYID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Unique identifier for a study.

children.name: DOMAIN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Two-character abbreviation for the domain most relevant to the observation. The Domain abbreviation is also used as a prefix for variables to ensure uniqueness when datasets are merged.

children.name: RDOMAIN
children.-DESCRIPTION: Domain Abbreviation of the parent record(s).

children.name: USUBJID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.
children.-Comments: Concatenate STUDYID, SITEID and SUBJID, separated by "-".

children.name: POOLID
children.-DESCRIPTION: An identifier used to identify a result from a group of subjects that is notassignable to a specific subject.

children.name: UDEVID
children.-DESCRIPTION: General name for a device.

children.name: UPRODID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Unique identifier for a specific device or collection of devices.

children.name: --SEQ
children.-DESCRIPTION: Sequence number to ensure uniqueness of records within a dataset for a subject (or within a parameter, in the case of the Trial Summary domain). May be any valid number (including decimals) and does not have to start at 1. Should be Assigned to be in a consistent chronological order.
children.-Comments: Sort by the key variables specified in the domain list. Assign --SEQ=1 to the first record and increment --SEQ by 1 for each additional record so that --SEQ is unique for each record within a USUBJID.

children.name: --GRPID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Optional group identifier, used to link together a block of related records within a subject in a domain. Also used to link together a block of related records in the Trial Summary dataset.

children.name: --REFID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Optional internal or external identifier such as lab specimen ID, or UUID for an ECG waveform or a medical image.

children.name: --SPID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Sponsor-defined identifier. Example: pre-printed line identifier on a Concomitant Medications page.

children.name: --LNKID
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifier used to link a feature (such as a tumor) initially recorded as a result in one findings domain to assessments of that feature in another findings domain. This may be a one-to-one or a one-to-many relationship. For Example: A single tumor may have multiple measurements/assessment performed at each study visit.

children.name: --LNKGRP
children.-DESCRIPTION: A grouping identifier used to identify a group of assessment results in one domain that are evaluated, as a group, and contribute to a (summary) result in another domain. This will usually be a many-to-one relationship. For example: Multiple tumor measurements/assessments will contribute to a single response to therapy determination record.

children.name: VISITNUM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Clinical encounter number. Numeric version of VISIT, used for sorting.

children.name: VISIT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Protocol-defined description of a clinical encounter.

children.name: VISITDY
children.-DESCRIPTION: Planned study day of VISIT. Should be an integer.

children.name: TAETORD
children.text: Planned Order of Elements within Arm
children.-DESCRIPTION: Number that gives the planned order of the Element within the Arm.

children.name: EPOCH
children.-DESCRIPTION: Epoch associated with the start date/time of the observation, or the date/time of collection if start date/time is not collected.
children.-Comments: 'SCREENING' if date of findings or start date of events/interventions is before RFSTDTC; 'TREATMENT' if date of findings or start date of events/interventions is between RFSTDTC and RFENDTC; 'FOLLOW-UP' if date of findings or start date of events/interventions is after RFENDTC.

children.name: --DTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Collection date and time of an observation represented in IS0 8601 character format.

children.name: --STDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Start date/time of an observation represented in IS0 8601 character format.

children.name: --ENDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: End date/time of the observation represented in IS0 8601 character format.

children.name: --DY
children.-DESCRIPTION: Actual study day of visit/collection/exam expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.
children.-Comments: Relative study day between <--DTC> and DM.RFSTDTC. Add 1 if the difference is greater than or equal to 0.

children.name: --STDY
children.text: Study Day of Start of Observation
children.-DESCRIPTION: Actual study day of start of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.
children.-Comments: Relative study day between <--STDTC> and DM.RFSTDTC. Add 1 if the difference is greater than or equal to 0.

children.name: --ENDY
children.text: Study Day of End of Observation
children.-DESCRIPTION: Actual study day of end of observation expressed in integer days relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC in Demographics.
children.-Comments: Relative study day between <--ENDTC> and DM.RFSTDTC. Add 1 if the difference is greater than or equal to 0.

children.name: --DUR
children.-DESCRIPTION: Collected duration of an event, intervention, or finding represented in ISO 8601 character format. Used only if collected on the CRF and not Derived.

children.name: --TPT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Text description of time when a measurement or observation should be taken as defined in the Protocol. This may be represented as an elapsed time relative to a fixed reference point, such as time of last dose. See --TPTNUM and --TPTREF.

children.name: --TPTNUM
children.-DESCRIPTION: Numeric version of planned time point used in sorting.

children.name: --ELTM
children.text: Planned Elapsed Time from Time Point Ref
children.-DESCRIPTION: Planned Elapsed time in ISO 8601 character format relative to a planned fixed reference (--TPTREF) such as "Previous Dose" or "Previous Meal". This variable is useful where there are repetitive measures. Not a clock time or a date/time variable, but an interval, represented as ISO duration.

children.name: --TPTREF
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description of the fixed reference point referred to by --ELTM, --TPTNUM, and --TPT. Examples: PREVIOUS DOSE, PREVIOUS MEAL.

children.name: --RFTDTC
children.-DESCRIPTION: Date/time for a fixed reference time point defined by --TPTREF in ISO 8601 character format.

children.name: --STRF
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifies the start of the observation as being before, during, or after the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics.

children.name: --ENRF
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifies the end of the observation as being before, during or after the sponsor-defined reference period. The sponsor-defined reference period is a continuous period of time defined by a discrete starting point and a discrete ending point represented by RFSTDTC and RFENDTC in Demographics.

children.name: --EVLINT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Evaluation interval associated with an observation such as a finding --TESTCD, represented in ISO 8601 character format. Example: -P2M to represent a period of the past 2 months as the evaluation interval for a question from a questionnaire such as SF-36.

children.name: --STRTPT
children.text: Start Relative to Reference Time Point
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifies the start of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable --STTPT.

children.name: --STTPT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by --STRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-15" or "VISIT 1".

children.name: --ENRTPT
children.text: End Relative to Reference Time Point
children.-DESCRIPTION: Identifies the end of the observation as being before or after the sponsor-defined reference time point defined by variable --ENTPT.

children.name: --ENTPT
children.-DESCRIPTION: Description or date/time in ISO 8601 character format of the sponsor-defined reference point referred to by --ENRTPT. Examples: "2003-12-25" or "VISIT 2".

children.name: --DETECT
children.-DESCRIPTION: The number of days from the start of dosing to the earliest detection of acondition or pathogen.
